build-tools/stx/debrepack.py.message:
Just a question about execution. When do we want to use things like the Python3 tarfile module instead of calling out to shell functions? We have dependencies on 'sort', 'awk', 'uniq'... the list is not insignificant and the code around shell callouts is almost always more than using python libraries. Anyway, just something to think about.

What happens if there is a directory but it is not a "top" directory? For example

masselst@yow-masselst-lx1:/tmp$ tar -ltzf maa.tar.gz
blah/
blah/gwenview.bhXQvC
blah/gwenview.DgSJDI
blah/gwenview.bhXQvC.part
gwenview.bhXQvC
gwenview.bhXQvC.part
gwenview.DgSJDI

A true "top" directory would be to review the return from "tar -ltzf" and the first entry, "blah/" in this case, is found on every other element of the tarball.
I will update the patch to cover a package with top directory and with one and only sub-directory.

In my primary version, I try to use the tarfile module than tar command, but the tarfile can't satisfy all cases, so somewhere is tarfile, and somewhere is tar command, that is ugly. Moreover, the above if condition of cmdx is copied from the untar.py of debmake python module. The debmake also doesn't use the tarfile, so I think tar is better.

The topdir.split('\n') of a tar ball without "top" directory is > 1, like the maa.tar.gz, it is 7. It goes to the else, no --strip-components 1.

Yes, the top directory is on every element, so the ouput of sort | uniq is 1.

In order to avoid it, it must mix the 2 output of calling tar twice, and then use more lines and method to parse the output. The run time should be faster than calling tar twice, but it is not readable and more easy for maintaining, so my preference to keep it, make sense?

Hmm, I wasn't aware that the mon_status command was removed, though it looks like the `ceph mon stat` command replaced it. The quorum status may be correct here, depending on what the contract of the return value is (its unclear actually what is the contents of the returned dictionary). If quorum_status returns the correct information required by calling code (which it appears to do so at cursory glance [0][1][2]), then this is generally okay with me but I do wonder if perhaps the code should be asking for the monmap over the admin socket since it can return information in other time. Perhaps that's another change which could be made in another PR.

Actually, looking at the calling code within the ceph-mon charm [1][2], it feels like the abstraction is actually at the wrong level. The code is using the mon map to iterate the monitors itself, which is fine but it has a complex data structure returned which requires the calling code to have intimate knowledge of this undocumented structure. It would be more clear if there was a get_monitors() method that returned a list of monitors.

Apologies for the tangent, I had to convince myself that this change was a correct change to make since it was confusing to me at first. I did want to make sure to note the interesting complexities here.

[2] https://opendev.org/openstack/charm-ceph-mon/src/branch/master/lib/charms_ceph/utils.py#L2138
The patchset itself looks good to me, although I agree with Billy's comment in that we need a true `Monitor` entity in the future to avoid using a plain dict with fixed keys as we are doing ATM.

This variable is called 'image_id', but 'create_server_image' returns an Image object, not an ID. You need to either rename the variable or modify what you're saving to it

This is failing for me with the following error message:

  $ openstack server image create dee08e72-e870-442a-b9ce-ed5df26b2b30                                                                                                                                               
  No Image found for Munch({'location': ..., 'minRam': 0})

This is because of the above. To be honest, I don't think we actually need this call anymore since 'create_server_image' returns an Image object but you should evaluate that by testing the command under various conditions (i.e. with and without different CLI flags)

As an aside, did you test this? Please test commands against your DevStack deployment or ensure you have functional tests in the gate to ensure obvious things like this don't slip through

`create_server_image` is returning an object of type `<class 'munch.Munch'>`

Ah, fair. The former is basically a dictionary wrapped up in a munch object, which allows you to do e.g.

  image.id

in addition to the standard

  image['id']

There's more info on this topic here [1]. I guess the SDK should convert this to a proper Image object but that's not your problem.

[1] https://github.com/Infinidat/munch
Ack. We decided to leave this as is after looking into what is being returned in both cases.

Ah, this is in the wrong place. It should be placed _after_ the potential wait call. If you don't do this, we fetch the image before the wait which means e.g. the status we show could be wrong ('pending' instead of 'active').

src/reactive/designate_bind_handlers.py.message: Would this be @when or @when_all? The difference is that bind would only get restarted, and the /etc/bind/stats.conf configured when the relation (e.g. with prometheus-bind-exporter) exists.

Apparently, @when and @when_all are the same thing[1], although @when_all is more explicit and as the Zen of Python says: "Explicit is better than implicit."[2]

I will change considerably this logic in the next patch, but the flag bind-stats.available is set when the relation with prometheus-bind-exporter is joined.

[1] https://github.com/juju-solutions/charms.reactive/blob/master/charms/reactive/decorators.py#L113-L131
[2] https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0020/#id2

If @when_all is used, setting this flag would not trigger the other function.

OTOH, be careful when using @when_not (or @when_any?) because you could run into a similar loop every time the update-status hook is triggered.
Are you sure that, skipping args will not harm anything?

I think the documentation is a little bit controversial about this topic. In one hand it says that should be explicit [1] and on the other hand, it uses in a implicit way in the charm-anatomy [2].

In our case, we can't add another @when decorator to the relation of the charm-designate-bind because is not all the bundles that will use this new interface, but at the same time, we should change the templates if bind-stats shows in action.

What is inside args is the endpoint related to the dns-backend and I'm just passing in a more explicit way with our new endpoint that can be ready or not.

In theory we are not skipping args, just passing it in a more explicit way with our new endpoint that carries the logic for named.conf and stats.conf respecting the logic before our changes.

[1] https://charmsreactive.readthedocs.io/en/latest/charms.reactive.decorators.html#charms-reactive-decorators
[2] https://docs.openstack.org/charm-guide/latest/charm-anatomy.html#rendering-a-template

manifests/api.pp.message:
Unfortunately this is causing duplicated declaration error .

The problem here is that the same oslo::middleware resource is defined in two places, nova::api and nova::metadata, and since the manifests for our integration tests (and usual puppet manifests) include both class.

Our integration tests intentionally or unintentonally workarounded the issue by setting nova_metadata_wsgi_enabled=true, but to make this resource available for every case then we should definitely invalidate the same resource in the nova::metadata class.

designate_tempest_plugin/tests/api/v2/te.message:
While I agree that the old code is broken in a general setup, this solution also feels strange to me, since an authorized user is needed to get the catalog. I don't know how to properly solve this, though, my only suggestion would be to skip it until we have a better idea.

Not directly related, I don't like the idea of doing three different tests in a loop here, those should be separate tests.

This is how other projects do this test. I am ok with requiring it to have a catalog (having an account is part of the test anyway).
To me it is more about the test itself rather than the setup. Our goal is to make sure that version discovery can occur without a token.
As for should this be split out into separate tests, there are arguments on both sides:
1. It makes disabling and isolating trouble tests easier.
2. With the new keystone personas there are now over nine personas, so multiplying every API tests into nine or more sub-tests does not seem workable. Iterating over personas inside API tests seems like a better approach.
3. Iterating over personas, when needed, inside the API tests keeps the test focus (unit of work) on the activity of the test and not details like personas.

Personally I would prefer to keep the tests focused on the unit of work than the iterations of personas.

senlinclient/tests/unit/v1/test_cluster..message: this kind of checking is not meaningful. it only tells us if the mocked response needs an update.

1. self.assertEqual(self.columns, columns) check columns we want to show.
If we change columns in cluster.py, we will get fail in this test line, and to think weather we really want to change, if we want to change we can also modify self.columns to pass this test.
 
2.But each element in columns we add need be parsed in openstack.cluster.v1.Node. We can't know weather this element is a property of the class.
If we add a element not the property of the class in openstacksdk side we will not show this element. We have many problems about this.
So we add this check, it not test mocked response, but indeed it can compare the columns we want with openstack.cluster.v1.Node.

For example action-list:
columns = ['id', 'name', 'action', 'status', 'target_id', 'depends_on', 'depended_by', 'created_at']
In server it respone 'target', in openstack.cluster.v1.Action it was coverted to'target_id'.So in columns we need set it is 'target_id', if we set it 'target' it will not show this line, if we use 'target' to filter, it will not be filtered.

Yes, you can cherry-pick this change locally and then re-submit it for review.

$head /localdisk/deploy/lat.yaml
name: debian-image-demo
machine: intel-x86-64

- iso

- deb [trusted=yes] http://stx-stx-repomgr:80/deb-local-build bullseye main

build-image installs the packages listed in both baes-bullseye.lst and stx-std.lst. Now the isc-dhcp and systemd are in both lists, build-image after build-pkgs may meet installing failure due to one package has 2 versions.

When I did this review https://review.opendev.org/c/starlingx/tools/+/818334, I met problem due to both versions.

In order to check which package needs the 2 new packages, I rerun the test on newest list. No package needs them any more, I will remove them. BTW, I found another duplicated packages of systemd, I will remove them as well.

My original review is https://review.opendev.org/c/starlingx/tools/+/818334, but the 5 packages have been merged by other review, so this review is changed to clean up the base-bullseye.lst and add the missing dependences.

If we remove systemd from base-bullseye, then debdownloader will not place it in deb-local-binary. build-pkgs will place stx built packages in deb-local-build.

build-image looks in deb-local-binary only, when it creates the base image. It will complain about missing systemd packages.

Ack, means the build tools were updated in the meanwhile to look in deb-local-build also. Last time I tested(not recently) that wasn't the case.

My ideal world:

We start with a good sane default config file from a trusted location such as linus' tree eg. arch/x86/configs/x86_64_defconfig .  If the rt folks have their own default config then we also use it.

Then our "tis_extra" fragment adjusts it to our needs.  By looking at our config fragment we can easily tell our deviations from the norm.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message:
Just got bitten by this bug myself, and since the Zuul logs from back in June are no longer available so there's no way to tell what exactly went wrong in the gate, I gave a recheck a try.

This now breaks because the _OID_NAMES attribute has been removed from cryptography.x509.oid in https://github.com/pyca/cryptography/pull/6272, which landed in Cryptogaphy 35.0.0, and https://opendev.org/openstack/requirements/raw/branch/master/upper-constraints.txt now references 36.0.0.

So, I guess magnum/magnum/common/x509/validator.py needs a rewrite before this can land?
Found change I44407703fbcf2da97c29a28043520c781ef4c3b2 which should address the change in cryptography, and took the liberty to rebase this change on that.

To whom it may concern: I have now cherry-picked this change

* to stable/xena (https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/magnum/+/819090) and stable/victora (https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/magnum/+/819062), where it applies cleanly and passes all tests
* to stable/wallaby (https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/magnum/+/819092), where it also passes all tests if applied on top of https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/magnum/+/783249.

So, given the fact that this change has already received a +2 and a +W and subsequently fell victim to gate breakage (I think), and it's a regression for something that was already fixed once in Ib93a7c0f761d047da3408703a5cf4208821acb33, could this please be given a fresh review?

Right now it looks like the deal breaker in master is really the change to the cryptography dependency. One part of this is addressed by https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/magnum/+/817908 (for cryptography 35.0.0) addresses. 

However, as of cryptography 36.0.0 (released on 2021-11-21) we're seeing an additional error:

    TypeError: Key must be an rsa, dsa, ec, ed25519, or ed448 private key.

An additional change to address that appears to be necessary, though I've looked into the code and I can't quite make sense of what that change should be. :(
Ugh, scratch the superfluous "addresses" in the prior comment please (botched edit).

Since this is labelled Backport-Candidate: this change is a clean cherry-pick to all stable branches back to Train; I've submitted backport changes to all of them.

The change that broke this (Ibbed59bc135969174a20e5243ff8464908801a23) landed in the Train cycle, so Stein and earlier releases do not need a backport.

roles/tobiko-cleanup/tasks/main.yaml.message:
What happens if there are zero tobiko resources selected by grep? I think we should handle such case too.

 openstack stack list -f value -c 'Stack Name' | grep "^tobiko\." | xargs -r openstack stack delete -y --wait

There basically will be nothing to delete so xargs will not execute any delete command:

```
(overcloud) [stack@undercloud-0 ~]$ openstack stack list

(overcloud) [stack@undercloud-0 ~]$ openstack stack list -f value -c 'Stack Name' | grep "^tobiko\." | xargs -r openstack stack delete -y --wait
(overcloud) [stack@undercloud-0 ~]$ 
```
confirm. just wanted to mention that there is no `-y` and `--wait` parameters for `openstack image delete` command

The GNU implementation of xargs always executes the command at least once, even if there is no inputs to pass as command arguments. Therefore stack delete subcommand would fail without the -r option that disable such a 'undesired' behaviour.
there is no field 'Name' for stack, just ['ID', 'Stack Name', 'Stack Status', 'Creation Time', 'Updated Time']

While reviewing this, I noticed that we were ignoring the result from the call to attach the volume, so I've proposed [1] as a patch to add this missing feature. If that patch merges first then this will need a small bit of rework and vice versa. Nothing big though.

In case it's useful, here's how I tested this in a basic DevStack deployment:

  # create a server
  $ openstack server create --network private --flavor m1.medium --image cirros-0.5.2-x86_64-disk --wait test-server

  # create a volume
  $ openstack volume create --size 1 foo

  # add a volume to the server
  $ openstack server add volume test-server foo --enable-delete-on-termination --tag bar

  # ensure the volume is present (you might also want to inspect nova-compute logs if it isn't)
  $ openstack server list
  $ openstack volume list
  $ openstack server volume list test-server

  # delete the server
  $ openstack server delete test-server

  # ensure the server and volume are gone (the volume should go because of the flag)
  $ openstack server list
  $ openstack volume list

I then repeated the above but without the '--enable-delete-on-termination' flag and ensure the volume was *not* deleted when the server was deleted.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/python-openstackclient/+/816491

This happens both before and after the modification.

sysinv api runs as user sysinv
sysinv conductor runs as root

the synchronized decorator accesses a file in 
/var/run/sysinv/

-rw-r--r--  1 sysinv sysinv    0 Nov 22 16:32 sysinv-KubeRootCAController
-rw-r--r--  1 root   root      0 Nov 23 20:00 sysinv-KubeRootCAStateUpdate

so this synchronized lock will not work if the file gets written by sysinv conductor first
I suspect you can just remove that new sync line.

Yes, that is the issue. When the dl_hook is designed, I have discussed this with YueTao. By now the common tools about decompression are installed into the building env by default. Maybe we can add more indication about this on the readme file (stx_deb_folder_layout.rst).
Space after # plus watch your line wrap.

Hold on, you're doing all this just to convert an rpm of source to a compressed tarball?  That's ok if the debian way to is avoid the rpm at all costs, otherwise can't you just do the extraction from rpm in the debian makefile?  I kind of expect these download scripts to just be doing the download.

The dl_hook is designed to keep a common way for getting the source code when the source code package isn't in a normal debian way. We need prepare the source code (sometimes debian folder) for the debian building. The *.orig.tar.gz will be generated from it. I think it will be better we follow the common rules because following changes about the building process are in process and special thing may cause extra issues.

I think I found the issue: Since we are not in Python, but in JavaScript, empty objects (including Arrays) will evaluate to True. Thus, you have to change line 101 to

const buildsContent = autohold.nodes.length > 0 ? ( ...

I think the version without the length check works in other places only because the property which is checked is set null and not to [].
